title: What does it mean to be a refugee? - Benedetta Berti and Evelien Borgman

multiple-choice.question: Approximately how many people around the world have been forced to leave their homes to escape war, violence, and persecution?
According to the UN's 1951 Convention relating to the status of refugees, what is the definition of a refugee?

options.label: A
options.text: Someone who is fleeing their country for economic opportunities

options.label: B
options.text: Someone who is a victim of natural disasters

options.label: C
options.text: Someone who is unable to return to their home country due to well-founded fears of persecution

options.label: D
options.text: Someone who is outside their country of nationality and is unable to return to their home country because of well-founded fears of persecution

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe people who leave their country for reasons not related to persecution, such as searching for better economic opportunities?
What are the primary reasons why many refugees are unable to travel by standard routes to reach their destination?

options.label: B
options.text: Limited access to shelter, water, or food

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the principle preventing a nation from sending an individual to a country where their life and freedom are threatened?
What is the most basic obligation towards refugees, as recognized by international law?

options.label: A
options.text: Guarantee of a minimum standard of treatment and non-discrimination

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why many refugees are left with no choice but to remain in camps for years and sometimes even decades?

options.label: A
options.text: Limited access to shelter, water, or food

options.label: D
options.text: Limited resettlement and long-term integration options

multiple-choice.question: What is the first legal step for a displaced person to take in a new country?
What is the term used to describe people who have been displaced due to natural disasters, food insecurities, and other hardships, but are not recognized as refugees by international law?
According to the transcript, what is the likely outcome for many refugee children who are out of school due to lack of funding for education programs?

options.label: A
options.text: They will eventually return to school

options.label: B
options.text: They will be able to access education programs through alternative means

options.label: C
options.text: They will be unable to access education programs and will be at a disadvantage in the future

multiple-choice.question: Approximately what percentage of the world's refugees are children?
According to the transcript, what is the primary reason why many refugees are unable to enter the workforce and are fully dependent on humanitarian aid?

title: The evolution of the book - Julie Dreyfuss

multiple-choice.question: What is the earliest object that we think of as a book?
Who is credited with introducing the printing press in the mid-15th century?

options.label: B

options.text: To make the books more aesthetically pleasing

options.label: C

options.label: A

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the most important life skills that few people know how to do?

title: The microbial jungles all over the place (and you) - Scott Chimileski and Roberto Kolter

multiple-choice.question: What term describes the vast communities of microbes that gather by the millions to form complex structures on surfaces?
What is a primary advantage of microbes living in a biofilm compared to living alone?

options.label: C
options.text: Access to a stable microenvironment with available nutrient sources

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the slimy, glue-like material that holds microbes together in a biofilm?
What term describes the phenomenon where individual cells in a biofilm differentiate into subpopulations with specific tasks?
What is the primary role of the extracellular matrix in a biofilm?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide nutrients to individual cells

options.label: B
options.text: To protect microbes from external threats, such as predators and physical dangers

What benefits do biofilms provide to humans and other species?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: They are responsible for environmental pollution

options.label: C
options.text: They provide tangible benefits, such as cleaning up oil spills, treating wastewater, and being normal and flavor-enhancing parts of many foods

options.label: D
options.text: They are not beneficial to humans and other species

multiple-choice.question: What term describes the complex interactions between microbes in a biofilm, including cooperative and competitive behaviors?
What role do predators play in the microbial world?

options.label: A
options.text: They provide nutrients to individual cells

options.label: B
options.text: They protect microbes from external threats

options.label: C
options.text: They seek to eat microbes, which can harm them and limit their access to resources

multiple-choice.question: What is the importance of biofilms to the global ecosystem?

options.label: A
options.text: They produce toxins that harm larger organisms

options.label: B
options.text: They are responsible for environmental pollution

options.label: C
options.text: They play a critical role within the global ecosystem by producing oxygen and participating in nutrient cycling

options.label: D
options.text: They are not important to the global ecosystem

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the phenomenon where one species eliminates another in a biofilm, resulting in more space and resources for the surviving species?
What is the role of the extracellular matrix in protecting microbes from external threats?

options.label: A
options.text: It provides a physical barrier against predators and physical dangers

options.label: B
options.text: It produces toxins to harm predators

options.label: D
options.text: It provides nutrients to individual cells

title: Why is the US Constitution so hard to amend? - Peter Paccone

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why the U.S. Constitution is difficult to change?

options.label: A
options.text: The founders of the United States wanted to create a unified country from thirteen different colonies.

options.label: B
options.text: The founders of the United States intentionally made it hard to change to prevent the agreements from being easily undone.

options.label: C
options.text: The Constitution's creators wanted to make it easy to change to accommodate the growing population of the United States.

options.label: D
options.text: The founders of the United States had no intention of making it hard to change.

multiple-choice.question: What is the threshold required for an amendment to be proposed in the U.S. Constitution?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: A two-thirds vote of approval in both houses of Congress, or a request from two-thirds of state legislatures to call a national convention.

options.label: C
options.text: A three-quarters vote of approval in both houses of Congress.

options.label: D
options.text: A unanimous vote in both houses of Congress.

multiple-choice.question: What is the process for ratifying an amendment in the U.S. Constitution?

options.label: B
options.text: Each state must hold a separate ratification convention with delegates elected by voters.

options.label: C
options.text: Each state must have its legislature vote on the amendment.

options.label: D
options.text: The amendment must be ratified by a simple majority vote in each state.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The Constitution's creators had no intention of making it easy to change.

options.label: C
options.text: The country has become less populated, making it easier to change the Constitution.

options.label: D
options.text: The founders of the United States had no intention of making it hard to change.

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: C
options.text: A ban on the burning of the flag.

options.label: A

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What question did British computer scientist Alan Turing decide to disregard in favor of a simpler one, which led to the idea of the Turing test?

title: This is Sparta: Fierce warriors of the ancient world - Craig Zimmer

multiple-choice.question: Which ancient Greek city-state was known for not having massive defensive walls?
What was the main purpose of the agoge in Sparta?

options.label: A
options.text: To teach young Spartans how to read and write

options.label: B
options.text: To turn a boy into a Spartan warrior through 13 years of relentless, harsh, and often brutal training

options.label: C
options.text: To promote the arts and music

options.label: D
options.text: To teach young Spartans how to dance

multiple-choice.question: What was the practice known as in Sparta where boys were whipped in front of an altar at the Sanctuary of Artemis Orthia?
What was the focus of a Spartan girl's curriculum in school?

options.label: A
options.text: Domestic duties and managing a household

options.label: B
options.text: The arts, music, dance, reading, and writing

multiple-choice.question: In Sparta, what was the practice of boys encouraged to do in order to survive, but with the risk of being disciplined if caught?

options.label: A
options.text: To steal food from their parents

options.label: B
options.text: To steal food from other boys in their training group

options.label: C
options.text: To steal in order to survive, but risk being disciplined if caught

options.label: D
options.text: To hunt for food in the wilderness

multiple-choice.question: What was the attitude towards bullying in Sparta?

options.label: A
options.text: Bullying was strictly forbidden and punished

options.label: B
options.text: Bullying was acceptable as a means of building resilience

options.label: C
options.text: Bullying was not tolerated and seen as a sign of weakness

options.label: D
options.text: Bullying was seen as a normal part of growing up

multiple-choice.question: What was the emphasis of Spartan education?

options.label: A
options.text: Spartan education placed equal emphasis on physical strength, mental sharpness, and emotional resilience

options.label: B
options.text: Spartan education focused primarily on physical strength and endurance

options.label: C
options.text: Spartan education focused primarily on mental sharpness and emotional resilience

options.label: D
options.text: Spartan education focused on the arts and music

multiple-choice.question: What was the purpose of the annual contest of endurance in the diamastigosis?

options.label: A
options.text: To test the physical strength and endurance of Spartan boys

options.label: B
options.text: To test the mental sharpness and emotional resilience of Spartan boys

options.label: C
options.text: To promote the arts and music

options.label: D
options.text: To teach young Spartans how to fight

multiple-choice.question: What was the expectation of a Spartan's loyalty?

options.label: A
options.text: To serve their family above all else

options.label: B
options.text: To serve their city-state above all else

options.label: C
options.text: To serve their country above all else

options.label: D
options.text: To serve themselves above all else

multiple-choice.question: What was the treatment of a Spartan boy who was caught stealing food in order to survive?

options.label: A
options.text: He was punished for stealing food

options.label: B
options.text: He was disciplined for being caught in the act of stealing

options.label: C
options.text: He was encouraged to steal more food to survive

options.label: D
options.text: He was ignored and left to fend for himself

title: Can wildlife adapt to climate change? - Erin Eastwood

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the most ancient solutions to adapting to climate change for some plants and animals?
Along what time scales does evolutionary adaptation usually occur?

options.label: B
options.text: Thousands to hundreds of thousands of years

multiple-choice.question: What type of changes are many plants, animals, and insects undergoing in response to climate change?

options.label: A
options.text: Heritable, long-lasting, and genetically coded changes

options.label: B
options.text: Nonheritable, short-term, and environmentally triggered changes

multiple-choice.question: What is happening to the tawny owl's plumage in response to climate change?
Why is the brown color variant of the tawny owl's plumage more advantageous in exposed forests?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is the genetically dominant form

options.label: B
options.text: Because it helps the owls avoid overheating

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is the recessive pale gray variant

multiple-choice.question: What type of changes have pitcher plant mosquitoes evolved to take advantage of warmer temperatures?

options.label: A
options.text: Heritable, long-lasting, and genetically coded changes

options.label: B
options.text: Nonheritable, short-term, and environmentally triggered changes

multiple-choice.question: Why are two spot ladybug populations shifting to the non-melanic color combination?

options.label: C
options.text: Because it helps them avoid overheating

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is the recessive pale gray variant

multiple-choice.question: What is happening to pink salmon in response to warmer waters?

options.label: A
options.text: They are spawning later in the season

options.label: B
options.text: They are spawning earlier in the season

multiple-choice.question: What type of changes are wild thyme plants in Europe producing to protect themselves against herbivores?

options.label: A
options.text: Heritable, long-lasting, and genetically coded changes

options.label: B
options.text: Nonheritable, short-term, and environmentally triggered changes

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated number of species on the planet that scientists hope to discover evolving in response to climate change?

title: Why are there so many insects? - Murry Gans

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated number of individual insects on Earth?
What is the approximate percentage of all animals on Earth that are insects?
What are some reasons why insects are able to thrive in extreme environments?

options.label: A
options.text: Their ability to adapt to new environments

options.label: D
options.text: Insects are able to survive in extreme environments due to a combination of factors, including their impressive adaptations, body armor-like exoskeletons, and small size, as seen in examples such as flat bark beetles living at -40F, Sahara Desert ants surviving at 155F, and bumblebees surviving at 18,000 feet.

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of insects' small size?

options.label: A
options.text: They are more vulnerable to predators

options.label: B
options.text: They are unable to occupy different niches

options.label: C
options.text: Millions of insects can inhabit a small space and make use of all available resources

options.label: D
options.text: They are unable to survive in extreme environments

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of an insect that feeds on blood?
What is the purpose of metamorphosis in insects?

options.label: A
options.text: To help them grow and spin cocoons

options.label: B
options.text: To help them feed on flower nectar

options.label: C
options.text: To maximize available resources in an ecosystem

options.label: D
options.text: To allow larvae and adults to occupy different ecological niches, such as the example of butterflies

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of insect species undergo complete metamorphosis?
What is an example of an insect that makes use of animal dung?
What are the benefits of insects' body armor-like exoskeletons?

options.label: A
options.text: They protect insects against the outside world

options.label: B
options.text: They help insects cope with habitats that other creatures can't

options.label: C
options.text: They make insects more vulnerable to predators

multiple-choice.question: What is the approximate number of known insect species?
What is the reason for the immense genetic diversity in insects?

options.label: A
options.text: Their ability to adapt to new environments

options.label: C
options.text: Their ability to breed and produce large numbers of offspring

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of insects' rapid maturation?

options.label: A
options.text: They are more vulnerable to predators

options.label: B
options.text: They are unable to occupy different niches

options.label: C
options.text: The cycle of reproduction resumes quickly, allowing for multiple generations in a short time

options.label: D
options.text: They are unable to survive in extreme environments

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of an insect that makes use of live insects?
What is the benefit of insects' ability to undergo metamorphosis?

options.label: A
options.text: To help them grow and spin cocoons

options.label: B
options.text: To help them feed on flower nectar

options.label: C
options.text: To maximize available resources in an ecosystem

options.label: D
options.text: To allow larvae and adults to occupy different ecological niches, such as the example of butterflies

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of insects make use of feces?

title: How ancient art influenced modern art - Felipe Galindo

multiple-choice.question: What style of art originated over 150 years ago and includes artists such as Picasso, Matisse, and Gauguin?
What was the primary inspiration for the movement that sought to create an entirely new style of art?

options.label: D
options.text: Non-Western cultures, including Polynesian and African

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the museum that Picasso visited in Paris in 1907, which housed a collection of African art?
What was the name of the painting created by Picasso in 1907, which is considered the first truly 20th-century masterpiece?
What was the reaction of the public when "Les Demoiselles d'Avignon" was first exhibited almost ten years later?

options.label: C
options.text: They were shocked, offended, and mesmerized

multiple-choice.question: Which artists drew on the aesthetics of African sculptures in their work, along with Picasso?
What was the name of the British sculptor who based many of his semi-abstract bronze sculptures on a replica of a chacmool, a distinctive reclining statue from the Toltec-Maya culture?
Which artist created a series of compositions, such as the geometrical series "Homage to the Square", that were inspired by pyramids and local art he encountered on his frequent visits to Mexico?
What term is used to describe the movement in art historians use to describe the influence of non-Western cultures on modern art?
What question deserves scrutiny, as artists continue to redefine standards?

options.label: A
options.text: Are artists playing the role of explorers or conquistadors, appropriating ideas and profiting from cultures they consider primitive?

options.label: B
options.text: Are artists creating art that is too abstract?

options.label: C
options.text: Are artists using too many colors in their art?

title: Why do we love? A philosophical inquiry - Skye C. Cleary

multiple-choice.question: Factual Question:
Conceptual Question:

options.label: A
options.text: According to Plato, love is the longing to find a soulmate who'll make us feel whole again, as described in his "Symposium".

options.label: B
options.text: According to Bertrand Russell, love is the desire to quench our physical and psychological desires.

options.label: C
options.text: According to Siddhrtha Gautama (the Buddha), love is a source of suffering that we should try to avoid.

options.label: D
options.text: According to Simone de Beauvoir, love is the desire to integrate with another and infuse our lives with meaning.

multiple-choice.question: Application Question:

options.label: A
options.text: If we rely too heavily on our partner for emotional support, we may become bored and trapped in a cycle of dependence, as described by Simone de Beauvoir.

options.label: B
options.text: If we experience the ecstasy of passionate love, we may be tempted to make it our only reason for being, which can lead to a lack of personal fulfillment.

options.label: C
options.text: If we don't love authentically, we may become stuck in a relationship that lacks intimacy and connection.

options.label: D
options.text: If we don't reach beyond ourselves, we may limit our personal growth and fulfillment.

multiple-choice.question: Analytical Question:

options.label: A
options.text: Plato and Schopenhauer have different views on the role of love in human relationships, with Plato seeing love as a means to become whole and Schopenhauer viewing love as an illusion that leads to suffering.

options.label: B
options.text: Plato and Schopenhauer agree that love is a necessary aspect of human relationships, but they disagree on its primary function.

options.label: C
options.text: Plato and Schopenhauer have similar views on love, but differ on the role of reason in human relationships.

options.label: D
options.text: Plato and Schopenhauer disagree on the role of love in human relationships, but agree on its primary function.

multiple-choice.question: Factual Question:
Conceptual Question:

options.label: A
options.text: According to Simone de Beauvoir, loving authentically involves supporting and enriching each other's lives.

options.label: B
options.text: According to Plato, love is the longing to find a soulmate who'll make us feel whole again.

options.label: C
options.text: According to Bertrand Russell, love is the desire to quench our physical and psychological desires.

options.label: D
options.text: According to Siddhrtha Gautama (the Buddha), love is a source of suffering that we should try to avoid.

multiple-choice.question: Application Question:

options.label: A
options.text: If we love authentically, we may experience personal growth and fulfillment, as described by Simone de Beauvoir.

options.label: B
options.text: If we rely too heavily on our partner for emotional support, we may become bored and trapped in a cycle of dependence.

options.label: C
options.text: If we don't reach beyond ourselves, we may limit our personal growth and fulfillment.

options.label: D
options.text: If we experience the ecstasy of passionate love, we may be tempted to make it our only reason for being.

multiple-choice.question: Analytical Question:

options.label: A
options.text: Plato and the Buddha have different views on the role of love in human relationships, with Plato seeing love as a means to become whole and the Buddha viewing love as an illusion that leads to suffering.

options.label: B
options.text: Plato and the Buddha agree that love is a necessary aspect of human relationships, but disagree on its primary function.

options.label: C
options.text: Plato and the Buddha have similar views on love, but differ on the role of reason in human relationships.

options.label: D
options.text: Plato and the Buddha disagree on the role of love in human relationships, but agree on its primary function.

multiple-choice.question: Factual Question:
Conceptual Question:

options.label: A
options.text: We may never know why we fall in love, but it will be an emotional rollercoaster ride that can bring both suffering and joy.

options.label: B
options.text: Love is a necessary aspect of human relationships, but its primary function is unknown.

options.label: C
options.text: Love is a trick of biology to make us procreate.

options.label: D
options.text: Love is a longing to find a soulmate who'll make us feel whole again.

multiple-choice.question: Factual Question:
Conceptual Question:

options.label: A
options.text: According to Simone de Beauvoir, love can be both a source of joy and a source of suffering.

options.label: B
options.text: According to Plato, love is the longing to find a soulmate who'll make us feel whole again.

options.label: C
options.text: According to Bertrand Russell, love is the desire to quench our physical and psychological desires.

options.label: D
options.text: According to Siddhrtha Gautama (the Buddha), love is a source of suffering that we should try to avoid.

multiple-choice.question: Application Question:

options.label: A
options.text: If we love authentically, we may experience personal growth and fulfillment, as described by Simone de Beauvoir.

options.label: B
options.text: If we rely too heavily on our partner for emotional support, we may become bored and trapped in a cycle of dependence.

options.label: C
options.text: If we don't reach beyond ourselves, we may limit our personal growth and fulfillment.

options.label: D
options.text: If we experience the ecstasy of passionate love, we may be tempted to make it our only reason for being.

multiple-choice.question: Analytical Question:

options.label: A
options.text: Simone de Beauvoir's views on love emphasize the importance of authenticity and mutual support in relationships.

options.label: B
options.text: Plato's views on love focus on the idea that love is a means to become whole and complete.

options.label: C
options.text: Bertrand Russell's views on love suggest that love is a desire to quench our physical and psychological desires.

title: What outer space does to your body

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of gravity on the spine when a person is on the ground?

options.label: A
options.text: It causes the spine to expand.

options.label: B
options.text: It compresses the spine, pulling it down.

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on the spine.

options.label: D
options.text: It causes the spine to move in a circular motion.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to a person's height in a zero-G environment?

options.label: C
options.text: The spine elongates, causing the person to grow taller.

multiple-choice.question: Why do astronauts experience back pain in space?

options.label: A
options.text: Because of the lack of gravity.

options.label: C
options.text: Because their spine is elongating and the body is adjusting to the new position.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they have not had enough rest.

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of gravity on the heart when a person is on the ground?

options.label: A
options.text: It causes the heart to become smaller.

options.label: B
options.text: It causes the heart to become larger.

options.label: C
options.text: It causes the heart to work harder, leading to increased blood pressure.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no effect on the heart.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the heart in a zero-G environment?

options.label: B
options.text: It becomes smaller and changes shape due to reduced blood pressure.

multiple-choice.question: Why do astronauts wear glasses in space?

options.label: A
options.text: Because of the lack of gravity.

options.label: C
options.text: Because their vision changes due to intracranial pressure changes.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are not used to the zero-G environment.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of running on a treadmill in space?

options.label: A
options.text: To give the body a break.

options.label: C
options.text: To simulate gravity and keep bones from atrophying and losing bone density.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the bones in a zero-G environment?

options.label: C
options.text: They change shape and lose calcium due to the lack of weight-bearing exercise.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it worth the risks for astronauts to explore space?

options.label: A
options.text: Because of the potential for scientific discovery.

options.label: B
options.text: Because of the technological advancements that can be made.

options.label: C
options.text: For the potential benefits to humanity and the spirit of exploration.

options.label: D
options.text: Because of the change in vision.

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of intracranial pressure changes on the eyeball in space?

options.label: A
options.text: It causes the eyeball to become larger.

options.label: B
options.text: It causes the eyeball to become smaller.

options.label: C
options.text: It causes the eyeball to change shape, requiring corrective lenses.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no effect on the eyeball.

multiple-choice.question: Why do astronauts keep different prescriptions of glasses on board?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide a backup in case the primary glasses are lost.

options.label: B
options.text: To allow astronauts to change their prescription as needed.

options.label: C
options.text: To accommodate the changes in vision that occur in space.

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of a zero-G environment on blood pressure?

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on the blood pressure.

options.label: D
options.text: It causes the blood pressure to become unstable.

title: History vs. Napoleon Bonaparte - Alex Gendler

title: #TEDEdChat: Redefining Leadership | Drew Dudley | Leading with Lollipops |

multiple-choice.question: What charity was Joseph Geni promoting on his first day of university?

options.label: B
options.text: Making someone's life better with a lollipop moment

options.label: A
options.text: He turned beet red and wouldn't even look at the woman

options.text: The importance of changing the world

title: The beneficial bacteria that make delicious food - Erez Garty

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of yeast in the production of bread?

options.label: C
options.text: To convert ethanol into acetic acid

multiple-choice.question: Which pathway does yeast prefer to use when making bread, and why?

options.label: A
options.text: The aerobic pathway, because it produces more CO2

options.label: B
options.text: The anaerobic pathway, because it produces more water

options.label: C
options.text: The aerobic pathway, because it produces less CO2

options.label: D
options.text: The anaerobic pathway, because it produces ethanol and CO2

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the small amounts of alcohol produced by yeast during bread-making?

options.label: A
options.text: They are consumed by the yeast

options.label: C
options.text: They are converted into acetic acid

options.label: D
options.text: They are trapped in the bread

multiple-choice.question: Which type of fermentation is used in wine-making, and why?

options.label: A
options.text: Aerobic fermentation, because it produces more ethanol quickly

options.label: B
options.text: Anaerobic fermentation, because it produces more CO2

options.label: C
options.text: Aerobic fermentation, because it produces less ethanol

options.label: D
options.text: Anaerobic fermentation, because it produces ethanol and CO2

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of bacteria in the production of red wines and chardonnays?

options.label: B
options.text: To convert ethanol into acetic acid

options.label: C
options.text: To turn a tart compound into softer-tasting ones

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the carbon dioxide produced during fermentation in a sealed container?

options.label: A
options.text: It is trapped in the container

options.label: B
options.text: It is converted into acetic acid

options.label: C
options.text: It is consumed by the yeast

options.label: D
options.text: It bubbles away through a vent

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of bacteria in the production of cheese?

options.label: A
options.text: To convert ethanol into acetic acid

options.label: C
options.text: To gobble up lactose and produce lactic acid

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of rennet in cheese production?

options.label: A
options.text: To convert ethanol into acetic acid

options.label: C
options.text: To help the process of curdling along

multiple-choice.question: What type of microorganism is responsible for the characteristic holes in Swiss cheese?

options.label: D
options.text: A species of bacteria that emits carbon dioxide

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of microorganisms in the production of various foods, including bread, wine, cheese, and yogurt?

options.label: B
options.text: To convert ethanol into acetic acid

options.label: C
options.text: To gobble up sugar and produce lactic acid

options.label: D
options.text: To culture and produce various compounds that contribute to the flavor, texture, and aroma of foods
